name: AH-200
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 5 function keys and arrow keys
graphics: Mode 2 : 256 x 192 with 16 colors (Hires mode)Mode 3 : 64 x 48 with 16 colors (Multi colour mode)32 sprites
sound: General Instruments AY-3-8910 Programmable Sound Generator3 channels, 8 octaves
ports: Joystick socket2 cardridge slotsRGB video outputCentronics interfaceAudio output
description: The Hitachi AH-200 is the same MSX 1 computer as the H2 but without the built-in tape recorder.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> JACQUARD BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote>Strange logo isn't it?</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (JUN. 83)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> We've wired CompuPro savvy into three of the industry most potent new processor chips. The result: more performance, more quality, more reliability, and higher speed for greater throughput than ever before.<br> CPU 286 and CPU 16032 can upgrade present systems to state-of-the-art operation, or serve as powerful fundations for new systems. CPU 68K, aside from being a superd CPU board, is also the core of our system 816/68K.<br> As always, CompuPro kept an eye on the future in designing these CPUs. With a CompuPro, you don't shudder a fast-changing technology, you welcome it.<br><br> We give you brains and brawn in one box, and that's beautiful. </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> QL MONITOR AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>It was actually a rebadged Taxan monitor</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1978 BROCHURE #6</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VICTOR ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>with the original Victor design.<br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The Victor 9000. It's a desktop system computer designed to be a "cut above" the rest...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> M5 PRO & M5 JR JAPANESE ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.pugly.juice.or.jp/pugly/oldpc/" target="_blank">Pugly</a> for this picture!</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY BROCHURE COVER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cover of a Tandy catalogue.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ARGENTINIAN ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.speccy.org/czarg/" target="_blank">CZARG</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEW ZEALAND ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>From left to right arrow, advert says:<br><font color="#666666"> Redesigned front panel. Totally synchronous logic design. Same switch and LED arrangement as original Altair 8800. New back.lit Duralith (laminated plastic and mylar, bonded to aluminum) dress panel with multi.color graphics. New longer, flat toggle switches. Five new functions stored on front panel PROM inc1uding: DISPLAY ACCUMULATOR (displays contents of accumulator), LOAD ACCUMULATOR (loads contents of the 8 data switches (A7.AO) into accumulator), OUTPUT ACCUMULATOR (Outputs contents of accumulator to I/O device addressed by the upper 8 address switches), INPUT ACCUMULATOR (inputs to the accumulator from the I/O device), and SLOW (causes program execution at a rate of about 5 cycles per second for program debugging). <br><br> Two, 34 conductor ribbon cable assemblies. Connects front panel board to front panel interface board. Eliminates need for complicated front panel/bus wiring. <br><br> New front panel interface board buffers all lines to and from 8800b bus. <br><br> Rugged, commercial grade Optima cabinet. <br><br> Full 18 slot motherboard. <br><br> New CPU board with 8080A microprocessor and Intel 8224 clock generator and 8216 bus drivers. Clock pulse widths and phasing as well as frequency are crystal controlled. Compatible with all current Altair 8800 software and hardware!. <br><br> New, heavy duty power supply: +8 volts at 18 amps, + 18 volts at 2 amps, -18 volts at 2 amps. 110 volt or 220 volt operation (50/60 Hz). Primary tapped for either high or low line operation.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Murray Moffatt</b> from New Zealand</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROF80 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert from Pentasonic stores chain.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 8-PAGE US ADVERT #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH LEAFLET</strong></font><br><blockquote>Opening to the computers universe.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #5</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> END OF LIFE</strong></font><br><blockquote>At the end of 1985, the entire stock of Alphatronic PC and peripherals is sold to brokers which sold them at 25% of the original price.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (DEC. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"9990 francs the TO9. Colors included" <br><br> "Thomson. All the world in a present"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT #2 (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">Compare the built-in features of leading microcomputers with the Atari personal computers. And go ahead, compare apples and oranges. Their most expensive against our least expensive: the Atari 400...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>''The sound, the color, the intelligence''</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TANDY 1988 CATALOG</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.switchtech.us/Tandy1000.html" target="_blank">SWITCHTECH'S Tandy 1000SX page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> STICKER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional adhesive sticker of the RC 700 Piccolo... What a visionary thought!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1980 ADVERT & PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>Price list</b><br><br>  <b>VP-111  </b>Low cost microcomputer  <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-114  </b>Expansion kit for VP-111 (3 KB RAM, I/O port and connectors)  <b>$76</b><br> <b>VP-711  </b>Original VIP microcomputer <b>$199</b><br> <b>VP-44    </b>On board RAM expansion (4 x 2114 RAM chips)  <b>$36</b><br> <b>VP-590  </b>Color board  <b>$69</b><br> <b>VP-595  </b>Simple sound board (256 programmable frequencies) with speaker  <b>$30</b><br> <b>VP-550  </b>Super sound board (Synthetiser with two sound channels  <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-551  </b>Super sound 4 channels expansion <b>$74</b><br> <b>VP-570  </b>4 KB RAM memory expansion board  <b>$95</b><br> <b>VP-580  </b>Two players keypad  <b>$20</b><br> <b>VP-585  </b>Keypad interface board  <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-560  </b>Eprom board for two 2716 EPROMS  <b>$34</b><br> <b>VP-565  </b>2716 EPROM programmer with software  <b>$99</b><br> <b>VP-575  </b>Expansion board with 5 expansions sockets  <b>$59</b><br> <b>VP-700  </b>4 KB Tiny Basic  <b>$39</b><br> <b>VP-701  </b>Floating point Basic (cassette)  <b>$49</b><br> <b>VP-710  </b>Game listings  <b>$10</b><br> <b>VP-720  </b>Game listings II  <b>$15</b><br> <b>VP-601  </b>Keyboard 128-character ASCII  <b>$69</b> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Tony Mattson for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Picture courtesy of <a href=§http://www.sbrowning.com/vintage§>Steve Browning, www.sbrowning.com/vintage</a>.</p></blockquote>

Panasonic  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W|||Scanner/Printer interface|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PANASONIC  FS-IFA1 & FW-RSU1W</strong></font><br><strong>> Scanner/Printer interface</strong><br><blockquote>The FS-IFA1 is the printer/scanner interface (left on the picture) and the FW-RSU1W is the handheld scanner (right on the picture). These expansions are for MSX2 systems.</blockquote>
Sony HBI-232|||RS232c cartridge|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SONY HBI-232</strong></font><br><strong>> RS232c cartridge</strong><br><blockquote>Used to connect serial printers.</blockquote>

Yamaha mouse #1||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This mouse was compatible with all MSX systems. It connects to the first Joystick port.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>
Yamaha mouse #2||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> YAMAHA MOUSE #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Brand new!<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>www.zonadepruebas.com</b></p></blockquote>

Philips VW0020|||80-col dot-matrix printer|||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PHILIPS VW0020</strong></font><br><strong>> 80-col dot-matrix printer</strong><br><blockquote>This printer was a rebadged version of the Seikosha GP-500.<br>  It was a 80-column, 50 CPS model with a 7x5 dot matrix head.<br>  Commodore and Atari used same hardware basis for their MPS-801 and 1029 printers. </blockquote>

Sanyo DR-202||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> SANYO DR-202</strong></font><br><blockquote>The ADSS system allowed to quickly search a specific program in a cassette tape and load it. Seach time for a C60 cassette was less than 1 minute.</blockquote>

Bit-corder||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> BIT-CORDER</strong></font><br><blockquote>Cassete recorder dedicated to Hit-Bit MSX systems, though it could be used with any home computers.</blockquote>

emulator.description: A MSX Emulator for Win95 and Win NT + Direct X

emulator.name: fMSX official Homepage
emulator.description: fMSX is a portable MSX emulator ported on : Amiga OS, Mac OS, MS DOS, OS/2, Sony Playstation, Risc OS, Towns OS, Unix / X, Win95 / NT, X68K.

emulator.name: openMSX - The MSX emulator that aims for perfection.
emulator.description: This new MSX emulator can reproduce, among many other MSX, MSX2and  MSX2+ machines, both Panasonic Turbo-R models. Be sure to get the catapult frontend and the system roms from FUNET.
